content.description: Make the face climb harder by staying left.  Obviously the arête is off.  The crux is in the middle section where the face is mostly blank except small crimps.
Super fun face climb on the right side of the main face.  When the river is high your basically over the water. Stay right and work up on crimps and finger jams to the top.
content.location: Right side of the main face.

content.description: Start by stepping up onto the ledge. The crux is probable the few moves off this ledge until you "get into" the corner with better holds. Follow the corner up occasionally stemming and finding the big holds.
content.location: This route goes up the obvious corner in between E.O.C. For Life and Master Mason.

content.description: Just another climb to try. Keep the swing in mind and don't stray to far left.  E.O.C. stands for the Environmental Outing Club at Keene State.
content.location: The face left of Fellow Craft Corner.

content.description: Perhaps a bit contrived, but a fun sustained route all the same.  Step up onto the Fellow Craft Ledge and head directly up the arête without using the corner.
content.location: The arête just left of Master Mason.

content.description: Don't remember the climbing being anything to special but the position over the river is cool.

This line is a variation of Archaic Arete but has a real life of it's own. Begin on that route and, after 20 feet, steer right, following the parabola up toward the apex of the bridge. Long before reaching the keystone, however, there is a block, conspicuously and contrastingly beige with a texture slightly grainier than its neighbors. Upon reaching it's left edge, shoot straight up to the top.
content.protection: small finger sized cams, wires. If tri-cams are your jam, I imagine they would be very useful.
content.location: Shares a start with Archaic Arete, which begins in the right facing dihedral at the river's edge.

content.description: Built in 1847 this beautiful bridge exhibits many artistic masonry design techniques.  The bridge is made up of thousands of quality granite blocks perfectly positioned without mortar.  The original purpose of this structure was to span the Branch River and expand the Cheshire Railroad.  Now it is just a historically relic with the bonus of a few good climbing routes.  Routes are almost always top roped from mason bolts but trad is possible.  The bridge is only about 45 tall but most of the routes are sustained face climbs with few rests.  The best climbs are on the north west side, the first section on the right as you approach.  There is plenty of sun here and it is somewhat sheltered from the wind.  If you climb other sections look out for poison ivy.  Although close to the road this spot is usually quiet with only the sound of the river peacefully flowing by.
